segment.source: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview
segment.target: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview

segment.source: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview
segment.target: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview

segment.source: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview
segment.target: Application Virtualization Server-Based Scenario Overview

segment.source: If you plan to use a server-based deployment scenario for your Microsoft Application Virtualization environment, it is important to understand the differences between the Application Virtualization Management Server and the Application Virtualization Streaming Server.
segment.target: If you plan to use a server-based deployment scenario for your Microsoft Application Virtualization environment, it is important to understand the differences between the Application Virtualization Management Server and the Application Virtualization Streaming Server.

segment.source: This topic describes those differences and also provides information about package delivery methods, transmission protocols, and external components that you will need to consider as you proceed with your deployment.
segment.target: This topic describes those differences and also provides information about package delivery methods, transmission protocols, and external components that you will need to consider as you proceed with your deployment.

segment.source: Application Virtualization Management Server
segment.target: Application Virtualization Management Server

segment.source: The Application Virtualization Management Server performs both the publishing function and the streaming function.
segment.target: The Application Virtualization Management Server performs both the publishing function and the streaming function.

segment.source: The server publishes application icons, shortcuts, and file type associations to the App-V clients for authorized users.
segment.target: The server publishes application icons, shortcuts, and file type associations to the App-V clients for authorized users.

segment.source: When user requests for applications are received the server streams that data on-demand to authorized users using RTSP or RTSPS protocols.
segment.target: When user requests for applications are received the server streams that data on-demand to authorized users using RTSP or RTSPS protocols.

segment.source: In most configurations using this server, one or more Management Servers share a common data store for configuration and package information.
segment.target: In most configurations using this server, one or more Management Servers share a common data store for configuration and package information.

segment.source: The Application Virtualization Management Servers use Active Directory groups to manage user authorization.
segment.target: The Application Virtualization Management Servers use Active Directory groups to manage user authorization.

segment.source: In addition to Active Directory Domain Services, these servers have SQL Server installed to manage the database and data store.
segment.target: In addition to Active Directory Domain Services, these servers have SQL Server installed to manage the database and data store.

segment.source: The Management Server is controlled through the Application Virtualization Management Console, a snap-in to the Microsoft Management Console.
segment.target: The Management Server is controlled through the Application Virtualization Management Console, a snap-in to the Microsoft Management Console.

segment.source: Because the Application Virtualization Management Servers stream applications to end-users on demand, these servers are ideally suited for system configurations that have reliable, high-bandwidth LANs.
segment.target: Because the Application Virtualization Management Servers stream applications to end-users on demand, these servers are ideally suited for system configurations that have reliable, high-bandwidth LANs.

segment.source: Application Virtualization Streaming Server
segment.target: Application Virtualization Streaming Server

segment.source: The Application Virtualization Streaming Server delivers the same streaming and package upgrade capabilities provided by the Management Server, but without its Active Directory or SQL Server requirements.
segment.target: The Application Virtualization Streaming Server delivers the same streaming and package upgrade capabilities provided by the Management Server, but without its Active Directory or SQL Server requirements.

segment.source: However, the Streaming Server does not have a publishing service, nor does it have licensing or metering capabilities.
segment.target: However, the Streaming Server does not have a publishing service, nor does it have licensing or metering capabilities.

segment.source: The publishing service of a separate App-V Management Server is used in conjunction with the App-V Streaming Server.
segment.target: The publishing service of a separate App-V Management Server is used in conjunction with the App-V Streaming Server.

segment.source: The App-V Streaming Server addresses the needs of businesses that want to use Application Virtualization in multiple locations with the streaming capabilities of the classic server configuration but might not have the infrastructure to support App-V Management Servers in every location.
segment.target: The App-V Streaming Server addresses the needs of businesses that want to use Application Virtualization in multiple locations with the streaming capabilities of the classic server configuration but might not have the infrastructure to support App-V Management Servers in every location.

segment.source: The Application Virtualization Streaming Server can also be used in environments with an existing electronic software distribution system (ESD).
segment.target: The Application Virtualization Streaming Server can also be used in environments with an existing electronic software distribution system (ESD).

segment.source: You use the ESD to manage streaming applications.
segment.target: You use the ESD to manage streaming applications.

segment.source: Unlike the Application Virtualization Management Server, the Streaming Server does not use SQL or a management console.
segment.target: Unlike the Application Virtualization Management Server, the Streaming Server does not use SQL or a management console.

segment.source: These servers use access control lists (ACLs) to grant user authorization.
segment.target: These servers use access control lists (ACLs) to grant user authorization.

segment.source: Package Delivery Methods
segment.target: Package Delivery Methods

segment.source: If you plan to use an Application Virtualization Server as the publishing delivery method, you need to determine which of the following package delivery methods your scenario employs:
segment.target: If you plan to use an Application Virtualization Server as the publishing delivery method, you need to determine which of the following package delivery methods your scenario employs:

segment.source: Dynamic package delivery
segment.target: Dynamic package delivery

segment.source: Load from file package delivery
segment.target: Load from file package delivery

segment.source: Dynamic Package Delivery
segment.target: Dynamic Package Delivery

segment.source: During dynamic package delivery, the server (Application Virtualization Management Server, Application Virtualization Streaming Server, or IIS server) delivers the virtualized applications to the end users through on-demand deployment.
segment.target: During dynamic package delivery, the server (Application Virtualization Management Server, Application Virtualization Streaming Server, or IIS server) delivers the virtualized applications to the end users through on-demand deployment.

segment.source: The server delivers the virtualized applications and packages to a client computer only when a user first attempts to launch an application (on demand).
segment.target: The server delivers the virtualized applications and packages to a client computer only when a user first attempts to launch an application (on demand).

segment.source: The server streams only the blocks needed to start the application (primary feature block).
segment.target: The server streams only the blocks needed to start the application (primary feature block).

segment.source: After the primary feature block is delivered to the client, the application runs; the client does not receive the complete application (incremental deployment) unless the client needs access to a part of the application that is not included in the primary feature block.
segment.target: After the primary feature block is delivered to the client, the application runs; the client does not receive the complete application (incremental deployment) unless the client needs access to a part of the application that is not included in the primary feature block.

segment.source: When this occurs, the client performs an out-of-sequence request and the secondary feature block is streamed to the client.
segment.target: When this occurs, the client performs an out-of-sequence request and the secondary feature block is streamed to the client.

segment.source: Dynamic package delivery allows for rapid application launch.
segment.target: Dynamic package delivery allows for rapid application launch.

segment.source: Load from File Package Delivery
segment.target: Load from File Package Delivery

segment.source: For load from file package delivery, the server delivers the entire virtualized application package to a client computer before the user launches the application.
segment.target: For load from file package delivery, the server delivers the entire virtualized application package to a client computer before the user launches the application.

segment.source: In this scenario, virtualized applications are delivered as a full package, rather than through the dynamic, incremental method used by the dynamic delivery model.
segment.target: In this scenario, virtualized applications are delivered as a full package, rather than through the dynamic, incremental method used by the dynamic delivery model.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For each delivery method, the initial virtual application delivery process and the virtual application update process are the same; the updated virtual application package replaces the original application package.
segment.target: For each delivery method, the initial virtual application delivery process and the virtual application update process are the same; the updated virtual application package replaces the original application package.

segment.source: The following table compares the advantages and disadvantages of each package delivery method.
segment.target: The following table compares the advantages and disadvantages of each package delivery method.

segment.source: Method
segment.target: Method

segment.source: Advantages
segment.target: Advantages

segment.source: Disadvantages
segment.target: Disadvantages

segment.source: Comments
segment.target: Comments

segment.source: Dynamic package delivery
segment.target: Dynamic package delivery

segment.source: Applications are delivered and updated on demand.
segment.target: Applications are delivered and updated on demand.

segment.source: Applications are delivered and updated incrementally to optimize launch time.
segment.target: Applications are delivered and updated incrementally to optimize launch time.

segment.source: Updates are delivered automatically to the client desktop.
segment.target: Updates are delivered automatically to the client desktop.

segment.source: Larger footprint in enterprise topology because of server requirements.
segment.target: Larger footprint in enterprise topology because of server requirements.

segment.source: Application streaming should be over a LAN; deployment scenarios over a WAN or that use an unreliable or intermittent connection between the server and client might be unusable.
segment.target: Application streaming should be over a LAN; deployment scenarios over a WAN or that use an unreliable or intermittent connection between the server and client might be unusable.

segment.source: Requires a streaming infrastructure.
segment.target: Requires a streaming infrastructure.

segment.source: Windows Installer used to deploy Application Virtualization Desktop Client software to end-user computers.
segment.target: Windows Installer used to deploy Application Virtualization Desktop Client software to end-user computers.

segment.source: Large enterprises should use Application Virtualization Streaming Servers as distribution points.
segment.target: Large enterprises should use Application Virtualization Streaming Servers as distribution points.

segment.source: Load from file package delivery
segment.target: Load from file package delivery

segment.source: Consistent with typical enterprise management practices.
segment.target: Consistent with typical enterprise management practices.

segment.source: Supports stand-alone configuration scenario.
segment.target: Supports stand-alone configuration scenario.

segment.source: Provides solution to micro–branch office problem.
segment.target: Provides solution to micro–branch office problem.

segment.source: Application delivery and update is not possible on-demand.
segment.target: Application delivery and update is not possible on-demand.

segment.source: Application delivery and update is not incremental; it increases resource consumption relative to dynamic delivery.
segment.target: Application delivery and update is not incremental; it increases resource consumption relative to dynamic delivery.

segment.source: The IT organization is often responsible for managing application licenses, user authorization, and authentication.
segment.target: The IT organization is often responsible for managing application licenses, user authorization, and authentication.

segment.source: Server-Related Protocols and External Components
segment.target: Server-Related Protocols and External Components

segment.source: The following table lists the server types that can be used in an Application Virtualization Server-based scenarios, along with their corresponding transmission protocols and the external components needed to support the specific server configuration.
segment.target: The following table lists the server types that can be used in an Application Virtualization Server-based scenarios, along with their corresponding transmission protocols and the external components needed to support the specific server configuration.

segment.source: The table also includes the reporting mechanism and the active upgrade mechanism for each server type.
segment.target: The table also includes the reporting mechanism and the active upgrade mechanism for each server type.

segment.source: Because these scenarios all use the Application Virtualization Management Server, you can use the internal reporting functionality that is built into the system.
segment.target: Because these scenarios all use the Application Virtualization Management Server, you can use the internal reporting functionality that is built into the system.

segment.source: If you use an Application Virtualization Management or an Application Virtualization Streaming Server to deliver packages to the client, packages on the server are automatically upgraded when a user logs into the client; if you use IIS servers or a file to deliver the packages to the client, the packages on the client must be upgraded manually.
segment.target: If you use an Application Virtualization Management or an Application Virtualization Streaming Server to deliver packages to the client, packages on the server are automatically upgraded when a user logs into the client; if you use IIS servers or a file to deliver the packages to the client, the packages on the client must be upgraded manually.
